skill.name: uv-package-manager
skill.description: Master the uv package manager for fast Python dependency management, virtual environments, and modern Python project workflows. Use when setting up Python projects, managing dependencies, or optimizing Python development workflows with uv.

skill.author: ActiveInferenceInstitute

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing no executable code. Provides guidance on using uv package manager through example commands and configuration patterns. No file system access, network operations, or credential handling.

content.value_statement: Managing Python dependencies with pip is slow and error-prone. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on using uv, an ultra-fast Rust-based package manager that is 10-100x faster than pip for installing packages, resolving dependencies, and managing virtual environments.
actual_capabilities: Initialize new Python projects with uv init command
Install and manage Python dependencies faster than pip
Create and manage virtual environments with uv venv
Install and switch between Python versions
Generate and use lockfiles for reproducible builds
Configure CI/CD pipelines and Docker builds with uv
limitations: Requires uv to be installed on the system first
Does not install uv itself - users must run installation commands
Does not execute commands - only provides guidance
Focus on uv features - does not cover other package managers in depth

output_examples.input: How do I create a new Python project with uv and add some dependencies?
output: â€¢ Run `uv init my-project` to create a new project with virtual environment
â€¢ The command creates .python-version, pyproject.toml, README.md, and .gitignore
â€¢ Add dependencies with `uv add requests pandas`
â€¢ Add dev dependencies with `uv add --dev pytest black`
â€¢ Run commands in the venv with `uv run python script.py`
â€¢ Pin Python version with `uv python pin 3.12`

best_practices: Always use lockfiles (uv.lock) and commit them to version control for reproducible builds
Use `uv run` instead of manually activating virtual environments to ensure correct Python and dependencies
Use `--frozen` flag in CI/CD pipelines to skip resolution and use exact locked versions
anti_patterns: Do not use pip alongside uv for the same project - stick to one package manager
Do not skip lockfiles in production - they ensure consistent dependency versions across environments
Do not ignore Python version pinning - always specify .python-version for reproducibility

faq.question: How fast is uv compared to pip?
faq.answer: uv is typically 10-100x faster than pip for installing packages, depending on the number of dependencies and network conditions.

faq.question: Does uv work on Windows, macOS, and Linux?
faq.answer: Yes, uv is cross-platform and works on Linux, macOS, and Windows with consistent command syntax across all platforms.

faq.question: Can I use uv with existing pip requirements.txt files?
faq.answer: Yes, use `uv pip install -r requirements.txt` to install from existing requirements files, or `uv add -r requirements.txt` to migrate them to pyproject.toml.

faq.question: How do I manage multiple Python versions with uv?
faq.answer: Use `uv python install 3.12` to install versions, `uv python list` to see installed versions, and `uv python pin 3.12` to set the project version.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using uv?
faq.answer: Yes, uv only downloads packages from PyPI and other configured sources. It does not collect or transmit user data. Package downloads are verified using checksums.

faq.question: How does uv compare to poetry and pip-tools?
faq.answer: uv is faster than both (6-10x), less opinionated than poetry, and simpler than pip-tools while offering the same lockfile functionality.
